section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary (countdown).
Begin Story Time by asking, What is the boy counting?
Read for enjoyment, with a focus on the counting sequence.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to 10 objects; Recognize and name numerals 0–9; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Identify rhyming words.
Say the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag and the state flag, and observe a moment of silence.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children count down as they remove manipulatives one at a time from a group.
Guide children to count the number of items shown on a Number Card.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? Why did you choose that one?
Use the dress-up clothes to make an outfit for the first day of kindergarten.
Can you count these 10 blocks in order?
Write about your favorite day in preschool. What made it special?
What materials could you use to make the number 9?
Use your finger to trace the letter C for countdown.
What did you build? Why did you build that?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder manage change and introduce vocabulary (independent, change).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Kindergarten Countdown!
Read closely to notice how the characters adapt to change and to review counting.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to 10 objects; Recognize and name numerals 0–9; Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children count a certain number of Connecting Cubes from a group of 10.
Challenge children to transition from working with partners to working independently.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me how to hold that book?
Can you pretend that it is the first day of kindergarten?
Find the number that shows how old you are.
What games do you hope to play in kindergarten? Write about them.
Make a name tag for your first day of kindergarten. Decorate it however you like.
Write your name on a name tag in big letters. How many letters are in your name?
Build a tower with 10 blocks. Can you count them backwards?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Kindergarten Countdown! by Marjorie Blain Parker, illustrated by Sophie Burrows. Text copyright © 2017 by Marjorie Blain Parker. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Sophie Burrows. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Sterling Publishing Company. section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary (before, after).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Kindergarten Countdown! and asking, What is one thing Tom does before starting kindergarten?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension, with a focus on measurement.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children tell whether an Activity Card depicts something they do before or after dinner.
Guide children to share and discuss their personal routines.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do things change in this character’s life?
Pretend you are walking into school on the first day of kndergarten! What do you see?
Count to 10. What number did you count after eight?
How do you think you will feel on your first day of kindergarten?
What are you making? What did you do before you started making that?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word before? Can you draw the letter that makes that sound?
Why do you need to put larger blocks down before you put smaller blocks when you make a tall tower?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Kindergarten Countdown! by Marjorie Blain Parker, illustrated by Sophie Burrows. Text copyright © 2017 by Marjorie Blain Parker. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Sophie Burrows. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Sterling Publishing Company.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I want to…

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss what children want to be when they grow up, engage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary (count, art).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts I want to… and Kindergarten Countdown!
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question, We’re ready. What’s next?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Count out a given number of objects from a group of up to 10 objects; Recognize and name numerals 0–9; Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Identify rhyming words.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Vote as part of a group to make decisions.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children a number and guide them to build a tower using that many Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to count the Connecting Cubes with one-to-one correspondence.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think this character will be when she grows up?
Pretend to be a teacher! How many students do you have?
Compare these two towers. Which one has more blocks?
What kind of job do you think would be the best for you?
Draw a bag to take to kindergarten. How will you decorate it?
Use your finger to trace the word count.
Build a house using blocks. How many blocks did you use? How could you add more?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Kindergarten Countdown! by Marjorie Blain Parker, illustrated by Sophie Burrows. Text copyright © 2017 by Marjorie Blain Parker. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Sophie Burrows. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Sterling Publishing Company.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to vote on a last activity and engage children in celebratory dance.
Start Story Time revisiting the book Kindergarten Countdown! and asking, What will you do to get ready for kindergarten?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination, with a focus on measurement.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count aloud 1–10 items, with one-to-one correspondence; Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities; Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Understand that people use different languages to communicate and express simple greetings and phrases in a language other than their own.
Recognize and understand how events, time, and routines relate to their lives.
Vote as part of a group to make decisions; Say the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag and the state flag, and observe a moment of silence.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Write a story about a child’s first day at kindergarten.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Imagine that this story continued. What would happen next?
Pretend you are on the kindergarten playground. What will you do?
Count your toes forward and backward.
Imagine you are writing to a child who will be in preschool next year. What will you say?
Use any materials to make something special to remind you of preschool.
Use magnetic letters to make the word PLAY.
Use blocks to make a school. Where is the kindergarten classroom?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Kindergarten Countdown! by Marjorie Blain Parker, illustrated by Sophie Burrows. Text copyright © 2017 by Marjorie Blain Parker. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Sophie Burrows. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Sterling Publishing Company.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize rhyming words.
Recite the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag and the state flag and observe a moment of silence.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Connect their lives to events, times, and routines.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Connect their lives to events, times, and routines.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Recognize rhyming words.
Connect their lives to events, times, and routines.
Engage in voting as a method for group decision-making.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Recognize one-digit numerals, 0–9.
Describe the passing of time.
Manage transitions, and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Use language for different purposes.
Connect their lives to events, times, and routines.
Engage in voting as a method for group decision-making.
Recite the Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag and the state flag.
